b.text: Use the same knife for everything

What does "Net Income" mean?

a.text: The total salary you are promised before taxes

b.text: The amount of money that actually hits your bank account after taxes

c.text: The money you earn from hobbies only

questions.question: What does the strategy "Pay Yourself First" mean?

a.text: Buying yourself a gift before paying rent

b.text: Paying off your credit card before your car loan

c.text: Asking your boss for an advance

d.text: Setting aside savings from your paycheck before spending on anything else

a.text: When your rent increases every year

b.text: When you spend more money as soon as you start earning more money

c.text: When you downgrade your lifestyle to save money

d.text: Moving to a more expensive city

questions.question: What is the main difference between a Checking Account and a Savings Account?

a.text: Savings accounts come with debit cards for shopping

c.text: Checking is for daily spending; Savings is for storing money long-term

questions.question: What does HYSA stand for?

a.text: It allows you to write checks

b.text: It is located in physical bank branches

c.text: It has a much higher interest rate (APY), so your money grows faster

questions.question: How much money should generally be in your Emergency Fund?

c.text: 3 to 6 months of essential living expenses

questions.question: Which of these is a valid reason to use your Emergency Fund?

a.text: A sudden car repair needed to get to work

b.text: A flash sale on designer shoes

c.text: Paying for a vacation you forgot to budget for

questions.question: What is "Overdraft Protection"?

a.text: A service that stops you from spending money

b.text: A bank service that covers transactions if your balance is zero (often for a fee)

d.text: A bonus paid by the bank

questions.question: What is "Compound Interest"?

a.text: Interest calculated only on the money you deposited

b.text: A fee the bank charges you for saving

d.text: Interest calculated on your principal plus the interest you've already earned

a.text: Paying off the loan with the highest interest rate first

b.text: Paying off the loan with the lowest balance first to build momentum

c.text: Consolidating all debt into one big loan

d.text: Paying only the minimums on everything

questions.question: What is the "Debt Avalanche" method?

a.text: Paying off the loan with the highest interest rate first

b.text: Paying off the smallest loan first

c.text: Asking your parents to pay your debt

questions.question: To maintain a good credit score, you should generally keep your Credit Utilization Ratio below:

b.text: It reduces your "Length of Credit History" and your total available credit limit

c.text: It increases your interest rate on other cards

b.text: When you check your own score

c.text: When you pay off a loan

d.text: When you get a raise at work

questions.question: Which of these is considered "Revolving Credit"?

c.text: You are charged interest on the remaining balance

c.text: A card with a $1 million limit

d.text: A card only for government employees

questions.question: Approximately what FICO score is considered "Good" to "Very Good"?

a.text: A Credit lowers your taxable income; a Deduction lowers your tax bill dollar-for-dollar

b.text: A Deduction lowers your taxable income; a Credit lowers your tax bill dollar-for-dollar

d.text: A Deduction is for the rich, a Credit is for the poor

questions.question: If you are in the 22% tax bracket, does all of your income get taxed at 22%?

a.text: Yes, every dollar is taxed at 22%

b.text: No, only your bonuses are taxed at 22%

d.text: No, only the income above the threshold for that bracket is taxed at 22%

a.text: To tell your employer how much tax to withhold from your paycheck

a.text: A scam to keep your money

c.text: A guaranteed 100% return on your investment (Free Money)

questions.question: What is the primary tax benefit of a Roth IRA?

a.text: You get a tax deduction now, but pay taxes when you withdraw

b.text: You never pay taxes on it ever

c.text: You pay taxes now, but all growth and withdrawals in retirement are 100% tax-free

questions.question: Which investment vehicle typically trades like a stock throughout the day and has low expense ratios?

What is an "Index Fund"?

a.text: A fund that passively tracks a market list (like the S&P 500)

b.text: A fund managed by a person who tries to pick winning stocks

c.text: A fund that only invests in tech companies

questions.question: If you withdraw money from a traditional 401(k) before age 59Â½, what usually happens?

c.text: You pay income tax PLUS a 10% penalty

questions.question: What is the "Rule of 72"?

a.text: A math trick to estimate how many years it takes for your investment to double

b.text: A rule that you must retire at age 72

c.text: A tax law regarding 72 types of income

d.text: You should save 72% of your income

questions.question: Why is "Time in the Market" generally better than "Timing the Market"?

a.text: Because you can predict the future if you wait long enough

b.text: Because stocks only go up on Tuesdays

c.text: Because compound interest needs time to work exponentially

questions.question: Which of these has historically provided the highest return over long periods (20+ years)?
What is a "Target Date Fund"?

a.text: A fund that helps you save for a wedding

b.text: An investment fund that automatically becomes safer as you get closer to retirement

c.text: A fund that guarantees you retire on a specific date
